channel.title: Ted Tschopp's AI News
channel.description: Latest AI News and Ratings from Ted Tschopp

item.title: NBIM accelerates sovereign wealth management with enterprise‑wide AI transformation [ ! ]
item.description: This is a large‑scale, real-world deployment in a regulated context managing $1.7 trillion in assets over 9,000 companies—exactly the kind of high‑impact use case that demonstrates AI at enterprise scale. Our analysts compared it to the JP Morgan case and emphasized how NBIM scaled AI adoption via “ambassadors” and top‑down mandate, underscoring the cultural as well as technical shift needed.

item.title: Understanding the 4 Main Approaches to LLM Evaluation [ ! ]
item.description: This article lays out a structured taxonomy of evaluation methods for large language models—benchmarks, judges, verifiers, and runtime evaluation—which is foundational for any AI team building or adopting LLMs. Our analysts agreed that article’s structured framing is critical for AI leaders to ask the right evaluation questions.

item.title: Front-Loading Reasoning: The Synergy between Pretraining and Post-Training Data [ ~ ]
item.description: The paper argues for injecting diverse reasoning examples during pretraining and focusing on high‑quality reasoning tasks in fine tuning. Our analysts panel found it intellectually worthwhile, but more relevant to researchers than applied AI practitioners right now.

item.title: State of Software 2025 [ ~ ]
item.description: This report delivers interesting metrics and trends across software markets in 2025. Our analysts considered it worthwhile for investors or tech watchers — but less immediately actionable for AI leaders.

item.title: Converting inbound leads into customers at OpenAI [ * ]
item.description: This is a useful case study of how OpenAI used a conversational assistant to personalize inbound lead interactions and improve conversions. Our analysts noted strong results in accuracy increase, though they wished the article gave more of how it was built and business results that were achieved.

item.title: Introducing CodeMender: an AI agent for code security [ * ]
item.description: CodeMender from Google DeepMind aims to detect and repair code vulnerabilities automatically, acting both proactively and reactively. Our analysts appreciated the ambition but noted it’s still research‑stage and raised concerns about side effects of automated fixes in complex systems.

item.title: Deloitte issues refund for error-ridden Australian government report that used AI [ ! ]
item.description: Deloitte’s refund underscores real risks in relying on AI without rigorous validation — a cautionary tale for any AI initiative. Our analyst team viewed it as a strong reminder to have Ai-in-the-loop and human‑in‑the‑loop safeguards, and to treat AI outputs with skepticism and continued oversight.

item.title: Introducing apps in ChatGPT and the new Apps SDK [ ! ]
item.description: This announcement lets developers embed or connect apps directly into ChatGPT, turning ChatGPT into a platform/operating system rather than just a chatbot. Our analysts emphasized that this is strategically significant — positioning OpenAI as a one-stop interface that threatens search and browser incumbents.

item.title: Introducing AgentKit [ ! ]
item.description: AgentKit offers a graphical, drag‑and‑drop way to build conversational agents, along with tools like evaluation kits, registries, and guardrails. Our analysts flagged this as a hugely important strategic step for OpenAI to compete with agent platforms, and noted its significance because it comes directly from OpenAI.

item.title: GenAI Promised a Creative Revolution. Can Marketers Deliver? [ ~ ]
item.description: This BCG survey discusses how marketers are adopting generative AI and the challenges they face. Our analysts saw it as having useful benchmarking data but not offering novel mechanisms for AI leaders to act on.

item.title: JetBrains Pioneers Multi‑Agent IDE Experience with Claude Agent [ ~ ]
item.description: JetBrains embedding Claude Agent in its IDE is a neat demonstration of integrating agents into developer tools — but the article lacks metrics or deep insight, so our analysts saw it as a light product story.

item.title: Agent Workflows by Eleven Labs [ ~ ]
item.description: Eleven Labs now lets users visually build branching, subagent‑based conversational flows, enabling per‑step model switching and custom behavior. But our analysts considered it more product update than paradigm shift, given how many workflow tools are emerging.

item.title: IBM claims 45% productivity gains with Project Bob [ * ]
item.description: IBM’s Project Bob is an enterprise-focused AI‑first IDE that orchestrates multiple models and integrates governance (AgentOps) to bridge prototype-to-production. Our analysts viewed it as a significant signal: enterprise AI is moving toward agentic workflows and governance, not just coding assistants.

item.title: How PowerSchool safeguards millions of students with AI‑powered content filtering using Amazon SageMaker AI [ * ]
item.description: This is a real-world use case of responsible AI — applying content filtering in education to protect vulnerable audiences. Our analysts emphasized that as AI agents enter regulated and sensitive domains (e.g. schools), mechanisms like this become core to adoption.

item.title: Petri: An open‑source auditing tool to accelerate AI safety research [ ! ]
item.description: Petri offers a tool for inspecting and auditing foundational models — not just a paper, but a concrete software artifact aimed squarely at alignment and model drift. Our analysts underscored that explainability, model oversight, and open alternatives are essential building blocks as generative AI scales.

item.title: LFM2‑8B‑A1B: An Efficient On-device Mixture‑of‑Experts [ ~ ]
item.description: This model enables on-device inference via a mixture‑of‑experts architecture (8B total, ~1.5B active), delivering performance akin to a 3–4B model on mobile and laptop. Our analysts appreciated the architectural ingenuity, but judged it a technical product release rather than broadly relevant to general AI strategy at this stage.

item.title: AI21’s Jamba Reasoning 3B Redefines What “Small” Means in LLMs [ ~ ]
item.description: Jamba Reasoning 3B offers a 250K context on a relatively small 3B‑parameter model, pushing the capabilities of “small” LLMs. Our analysts broadly agreed it is interesting in a crowded space of small models, but they did not see it as differentiated enough right now to demand broader attention.

item.title: Introducing the Gemini 2.5 Computer Use model [ ~ ]
item.description: The Gemini 2.5 Computer Use model can navigate web interfaces (click, type, scroll) — a move toward more agent-like capabilities in browser environments. But our analysts characterized it as a “catch-up” feature from Google, limited currently to web-level controls and not yet mature enough to merit higher urgency.

item.title: Ling‑1T [ * ]
item.description: Ling‑1T is a trillion‑parameter model optimized for reasoning and scaling, incorporating innovations like “EVO‑CoT” (evolutionary chain-of-thought) and a 128K context window. Our analysts flagged it as noteworthy because of its algorithmic advances and open architecture, and as a sign that China is pushing aggressively on the open AI frontier.

item.title: Vxceed builds the perfect sales pitch for sales teams at scale using Amazon Bedrock [ ! ]
item.description: This piece demonstrates a deployed, revenue‑impacting use of multi‑agent AI, showing how Vxceed built a “storyteller” framework on Amazon Bedrock to generate personalized pitches at scale — a concrete example of AI-driven sales automation. Our analysts emphasized that it’s not just a prototypical use case but in production, includes multiple cooperating agents, and offers a blueprint for organizations to emulate.

item.title: Less is More: Recursive Reasoning with Tiny Networks [ ~ ]
item.description: This research explores an algorithmic innovation (a tiny recursive model) that challenges the “bigger is always better” scaling narrative. Though compelling and innovative, our analysts saw it as academic and speculative for now.

item.title: BLACKBOX chooses ElevenLabs Agents over OpenAI to power Logger and Robocoder [ ~ ]
item.description: The announcement reads more like a marketing claim than a deeply informative use case; our analysts found little technical or business depth in its execution or outcomes.

item.title: Echelon's AI agents take aim at Accenture and Deloitte consulting models [ ~ ]
item.description: It’s an intriguing startup angle on reimagining consulting via AI wrappers around enterprise systems, but our analysts judged it as nascent and speculative, with limited traction or proof.

item.title: HiBob turns 2,500 GPTs into a flywheel for product and team growth [ * ]
item.description: This case study gives a concrete view of how an organization is deploying many GPTs internally for tasks like meeting prep, upsell opportunity detection, project management, and roadmap planning. Our analysts appreciated the ambition but flagged the lack of clear metrics, governance, and business outcome detail.

item.title: Introducing Figure 03 [ * ]
item.description: Figure’s new humanoid robot pushes forward the frontier of general‑purpose home robotics, with improvements in sensing, manufacturability, and software systems. Our analysts saw real potential — particularly in vertical integration, home assistance, and the broader robotics roadmap — while also noting it remains a flashy product announcement with early claims.

item.title: Introducing Gemini Enterprise [ ! ]
item.description: This is a substantial enterprise AI launch from Google, combining agentic capabilities, infrastructure, connectors, and governance in one platform. Our analysts emphasized that it's more than a product—it’s a strategic “front door” for organizations to approach AI at scale.

item.title: Novo Nordisk accelerates clinical documentation and drug development with Claude [ ~ ]
item.description: This case study claims a 90% time savings in regulatory document preparation using Claude for clinical trial reporting. However, the analysis pointed out the lack of clarity on whether these gains applied to initial drafting or final submission, making it less actionable for those outside life sciences.

item.title: A small number of samples can poison LLMs of any size [ * ]
item.description: Anthropic researchers show that injecting just a handful of malicious samples during fine-tuning can reliably poison LLM outputs, regardless of model size. Analysts flagged this as an important security wake-up call, especially as enterprises ramp up fine-tuning efforts, highlighting the need for rigorous data controls and new LLM safety mechanisms.

item.title: The Trillion Dollar AI Software Development Stack [ * ]
item.description: Andreessen Horowitz outlines how AI-native software stacks are transforming enterprise software development, emphasizing the strategic need for productivity gains and tool adoption. Analysts positioned this as a key resource for CIOs and CTOs, noting that companies lagging in GenAI adoption risk becoming obsolete, especially as consulting firms evolve into tech-first service providers.

item.title: HYGH accelerates development and campaign delivery with ChatGPT Business [ * ]
item.description: This case study highlights how HYGH uses ChatGPT Business across departments to enhance content and campaign development workflows. While somewhat fragmented in its presentation, our analysts noted its relevance in illustrating OpenAI's shift toward full-stack AI operating models and the broader industry trend toward AI-augmented operations.

item.title: How we scaled inbound sales with an AI SDR that qualifies 76% of leads end-to-end [ * ]
item.description: Eleven Labs created an AI sales development rep ("John") that achieved a 78% success rate in lead qualification, powered by multi-model orchestration and tool integration. While the agent design and prompting guide offer meaningful insights into building autonomous agents, the article was criticized for feeling like a vendor pitch, lacking external validation or outbound capabilities.

item.title: The State of AI Report 2025 [ ! ]
item.description: This comprehensive report offers a wide-ranging analysis of the AI landscape across industries such as technology, healthcare, finance, and manufacturing, blending technical, policy, and market insights. Our analysts emphasized its value as a reference for AI leaders advocating for AI literacy and investment, citing benchmarks (OpenAI's lead, China's rise), fine-tuning dominance by QLoRA, reinforcement learning trends, and the emergence of model context protocols.

item.title: How Agentic AI Is Transforming Enterprise Platforms [ ~ ]
item.description: This article offers a high-level perspective on how agentic AI is changing the structure and capabilities of enterprise platforms. The team found it added little beyond general framing, with no actionable detail or unique technical insight, making it an optional read for AI leaders.

item.title: Copilot helps one of Canada's largest credit unions go beyond the numbers to create more personalized service [ ~ ]
item.description: This case study describes Copilot's role in improving customer service at a Canadian credit union. Our analysts criticized the article for being vague, lacking measurable outcomes, and offering little insight into Copilot Studio's technical constraints, which undercut its value for enterprise AI leaders.

item.title: Meet Amazon Quick Suite: The agentic AI application reshaping how work gets done [ ~ ]
item.description: Amazon's QuickSuite is a new agentic productivity platform aimed at competing with Microsoft Copilot Studio, targeting AWS customers. Our analysts described it as a solid product drop but primarily relevant for those in the Amazon ecosystem and part of a crowded market of emerging agent frameworks.

item.title: Why AI Will Widen the Gap Between Superstars and Everybody Else [ ~ ]
item.description: This article argues that GenAI will amplify high performers more than uplift average users, potentially increasing organizational inequality. Our analysts felt the piece lacked empirical backing and original insights, viewing it more as an opinion piece that missed a deeper analysis of early adopter advantages or the real distributional impacts of AI at work.

item.title: Agentic Context Engineering: Evolving Contexts for Self-Improving Language Models [ * ]
item.description: This research paper introduces a three-part framework: generator, reflector, and curator, for improving LLMs by refining context (prompts, memories, evidence) rather than retraining models. While still theoretical, our analysts viewed it as an important early architecture for agentic systems, particularly for R&D teams exploring agent role definition, memory persistence, and team-level self-improvement in AI environments.

item.title: How Mr. Cooper assembled a "team" of AI agents to handle complex mortgage questions [ ! ]
item.description: This article outlines how Mr. Cooper deployed a system called CIERA, a multi-agent AI network designed to address complex mortgage queries, showcasing clear examples of orchestration across specialist agents. Our analysts highlighted it as a highly transferable enterprise pattern for AI leaders, emphasizing its value in visualizing and communicating agentic system design to overwhelmed executives navigating the emerging AI-first enterprise paradigm.

item.title: Introducing MAI‑Image‑1, debuting in the top 10 on LMArena [ ~ ]
item.description: While interesting from a product and branding standpoint (Microsoft’s first in-house text-to-image model, now ranking in LMArena’s top 10), our analysts considered it a data point rather than a paradigm-shifting announcement. Without full benchmarks or deployment details, it ranks lower in urgency.

item.title: Salesforce and OpenAI Partner Across Enterprise Work and Commerce [ * ]
item.description: By surfacing Salesforce’s Agentforce 360 inside ChatGPT (and Slack) and embedding frontier models, this partnership signals how workflow tools will increasingly become agent-driven interfaces. Our analysts saw it as a major signal of the direction enterprise software is heading, but debate remained about Salesforce’s execution credibility.

item.title: Kitsa transforms clinical trial site selection with Amazon Quick Automate [ * ]
item.description: This case study offers a concrete, measurable example of generative AI workflow automation in a high-stakes domain (clinical trials), citing improvements like 96 % faster data acquisition and 91 % cost savings. Our analysts considered it well-executed, though they flagged that many numbers are self‑reported and tied to AWS’s tooling.

item.title: Introducing LLM‑Evalkit: A practical framework for prompt engineering on Google Cloud [ * ]
item.description: The LLM Evalkit helps turn prompt engineering from intuition-based approaches into an instrumented, structured evaluation process, supporting better model development and deployment. Our analysts noted that this creates engineering discipline around prompts and reduces the ad hoc nature of many current evaluation practices.

item.title: The Gen AI Playbook for Organizations [ ! ]
item.description: This article frames generative AI not just as a tool but as a capability to build into an organization, with frameworks around experimentation, value-mapping, and governance. Our analysts emphasized that thinking of AI as a capability (vs. just a technology) is critical to gaining competitive advantage, making this a must-read for enterprise AI leaders.

item.title: You’ll soon be able to shop Walmart from ChatGPT [ ! ]
item.description: Walmart announced that customers will soon be able to search for and purchase items directly through ChatGPT, using a new integration powered by OpenAI. Our analysts saw this as a tectonic shift in the evolution of “AI-first shopping,” with vast implications for brands, marketplaces, and competition.

item.title: Introducing Claude Haiku 4.5 [ ~ ]
item.description: Anthropic’s Haiku 4.5 targets cost‑efficient deployment in agent settings, matching performance of larger models for certain tasks. Our analysts considered this as a routine product announcement, thereby classifying it as optional.

item.title: The Big Rethink: An agenda for thriving in the agentic age [ ~ ]
item.description: McKinsey frames a high-level leadership agenda for adopting autonomous “agentic” systems. Our analysts judged it conceptually interesting but too abstract or thin to be actionable, placing it in the optional bucket.

item.title: Inside the AI-powered assistant helping doctors work faster and better at Seattle Children’s Hospital [ * ]
item.description: In a major health system spanning 47 sites, Google Cloud’s “Pathway Assistant” is being applied to streamline clinician workflows (not decision-making), representing meaningful deployment of AI in healthcare. Our analysts acknowledged the potential impact while noting weaker quantification of business outcomes.

item.title: eSentire scales elite cybersecurity expertise with Claude in Amazon Bedrock [ * ]
item.description: This case study shows how a security firm is embedding Claude agents into Bedrock to automate incident response, delivering orchestration across multiple agents and generating incremental revenue. Our analysts found the use case compelling in the critical domain of cybersecurity even though it lacks implementation details.

item.title: Introducing Veo 3.1 and new creative capabilities in the Gemini API [ * ]
item.description: Google’s Veo 3.1 brings significant enhancements in AI video generation—adding improved prompt adherence, audio integration, object insertion/removal, and better editing controls. Our analysts agreed that this gives marketers and creatives precise control over visual style, pacing, and continuity using just a few reference images and shows how images and video can be used to elevate campaigns and engage audiences at scale.

item.title: Generative AI and Firm Productivity: Field Experiments in Online Retail [ ! ]
item.description: This paper provides rare causal, real‑world evidence that generative AI can boost firm productivity—reporting sales lifts of up to 16.3 % and an implied ~$5 incremental value per consumer. Our analysts flagged it as “absolutely essential,” noting it avoids hand‑wavy claims and instead delivers rigorous, quantitative insight.
